item.title: 2 U.S. Nationals Charged for Conspiring to Feed Russia’s ‘War Machine’
item.description: Five Russians were also charged in the scheme. And U.S. officials are said to be answering Kyiv’s plea for Patriot missiles, the premier air-defense weapon in the American arsenal.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The frontline city of Bakhmut in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Somalis Are Dying of Hunger. Officials Say It’s Not a Famine. Why?
item.description: An official declaration of famine would unleash aid and attention. Some experts say Somalia shows that the international system for making the judgment is broken.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali Muhammed held his 3-year-old son Isaac at a nutrition center run by Save the Children and World Vision in Baidoa, Somalia, last month.

item.title: Prince Accused of Plot in Germany Is Said to Have Visited Russian Diplomats
item.description: Closed briefings by police investigators divulged extensive new plot details to German lawmakers — from death vows to caches of bullets.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince Heinrich XIII of Reuss’s Waidmannsheil lodge in Bad Lobenstein, Germany.

item.title: South Africa Rejects Impeachment Inquiry of President Cyril Ramaphosa
item.description: Legislators with the African National Congress party voted not to hold impeachment hearings of their embattled president, Cyril Ramaphosa, giving him a political lift amid the scandal known as “Farmgate.”
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa came under scrutiny after he failed to inform police about a break-in at this farm.

item.title: Joy and Anxiety Collide as Moroccans Look to World Cup Match With France
item.description: Morocco’s magical run has elated fans, but for some, the strain of the impending showdown with the country’s former colonial overlords is too much.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
item.media:credit: Imane Djamil for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ksar el Kebir has made efforts to develop Moroccan soccer talent: new sports academies, new stadiums and new training programs.

item.title: As Morocco and France Prepare for World Cup, Historical Tensions Swirl
item.description: Wednesday’s face-off between the Atlas Lions and Les Bleus will be about more than just soccer, reviving old colonial wounds and fueling identity debates.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Tom Nouvian
item.media:description: Morocco supporters in Paris celebrating the team’s win over Portugal to reach the semifinals in the World Cup.

item.title: Concern Grows in Israel’s Military as Netanyahu Nears Coalition Deal
item.description: Preliminary agreements between Benjamin Netanyahu and his far-right allies have raised questions about political interference in the army’s chain of command.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu has held coalition talks that could see parts of the military hierarchy in the West Bank placed under the authority of two far-right politicians.

item.title: Ukraine Targets Melitopol, Hinting at Next Front in the War with Russia
item.description: Using missiles and saboteurs, Ukraine is focusing on the city of Melitopol, a vital Russian link to Crimea, ahead of an expected southern offensive.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The site of a car bomb explosion outside a building housing a local TV station in Melitopol in October.

item.title: Violence Grows in Peru After President Pedro Castillo Is Ousted
item.description: At least six people have been killed in violence that has spread across the country following last week’s impeachment of Pedro Castillo after he tried to dissolve Congress.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj, Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Supporters of former President Pedro Castillo clashing with riot police during a protest near the Congress in Lima, Peru, on Monday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Unveils Plans to Tackle Migrant Boat Crossings and Asylum Backlog
item.description: Amid growing anger within his governing Conservative Party, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak vowed to eliminate the country’s backlog of asylum claims.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A lifeboat on the southeast coast of Britain with migrants picked up at sea while attempting to cross the English Channel in June.

item.title: French Court Convicts 8 of Aiding 2016 Terrorist Attack in Nice
item.description: The defendants were found guilty of helping the perpetrator prepare for the assault in which he plowed a truck into a Bastille Day crowd, killing 86 people.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in Nice, in southern France, to the victims of the terrorist attack that killed 86 people in 2016.

item.title: In Libya, Mystery Shrouds Handover of Lockerbie Suspect to US
item.description: Abu Agila Mohammad Mas’ud, a former intelligence officer accused of delivering the bomb that destroyed a passenger jet mid flight in 1988, was abducted from his home, according to relatives.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Paul Hudson with a picture of his daughter, Melina, and photographs of almost 100 other victims of the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, outside a Washington courthouse on Monday.

item.title: Indian and Chinese Soldiers Again Trade Blows at Disputed Border
item.description: Tensions are still simmering two years after a deadly confrontation over a remote region each country claims as its own.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: A convoy of Indian Army trucks traveling a road to the Tawang area in the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh last year.

item.title: Iran Carries Out Second Execution Linked to Protests
item.description: In the second execution in just a few days, a 23-year-old protester was hanged from a construction crane at dawn in the city of Mashhad, galvanizing a new wave of demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Photographs of Mohsen Shekari, left, and Majid Reza Rahnavard during a demonstration on Monday in Berlin, Germany.

item.title: Countries Pledge $1 Billion in Aid for Ukraine
item.description: A French-led effort to involve dozens of countries aims to help Ukraine survive a harsh winter with quick repair of vital electrical, heating, water and health care systems.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: World leaders on Tuesday announced more than $1 billion in swift aid for Ukraine to repair the destroyed country.

item.title: Biden Hosts African Leaders for Talks on Security, Trade and Outer Space
item.description: Nearly 50 African heads of state are attending the first U.S.-Africa summit since 2014. It opened with sessions on civil conflict, democracy and space exploration.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The first day of meetings at the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit centered on critical topics including the environment, public health, democratic governance and security.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Nuclear Fusion Breakthrough
item.description: Plus Argentina beat Croatia to advance to the World Cup finals.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: An inspection of a final optics assembly during routine maintenance at the National Ignition Facility of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.

item.title: Belarus Checks Army Readiness as Analysts Say It Is Unlikely to Join Ukraine War
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus is a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and Belarus relies on Moscow for finance, fuel and security assistance.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus is a close ally of Russia.

item.title: Removal of Banksy Work in Ukraine Sparks Debate Around the Future Of His Murals
item.description: The removal of a Banksy mural sparks a debate about the future of a handful of his works scattered in and around Ukraine’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A dancer posing near a stenciled painting attributed to Banksy. The work shows a gymnast appearing to do a handstand on the rubble of a destroyed building in Borodianka, near the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv.

item.title: Europe Reaches Deal for Carbon Tax Law on Imports
item.description: If approved, as expected, the plan would impose tariffs on countries that fail to take strict steps to curb their greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:description: A steel factory in Shanghai in September. China would be affected by the new law, alongside other E.U. trade partners.

item.title: As Covid Spreads Fast in China, Beijing Isn’t in Lockdown. But It Feels Like It.
item.description: Almost no one is venturing out even after an easing of pandemic measures. Cold and flu medicines are scarce, but food supplies appear adequate.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and David Pierson
item.media:description: Delivery drivers, usually ubiquitous in Beijing, have nearly vanished because of Covid infections.

item.title: Jin, Eldest BTS Member, Enlists in South Korean Army
item.description: Saying goodbye to the ARMY — as the K-pop supergroup’s fan base is known — and hello to the armed forces, Jin became the first member of the boy band to start mandatory military service.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A fan of BTS singer Jin holding up his photo in front of a military training facility in Gyeonggi Province, South Korea, where he began his mandatory military service.

item.title: ‘There Must Be More Room for Africa,’ Leader of African Union Says
item.description: President Macky Sall of Senegal, chairman of the bloc, said in an interview before the U.S.-Africa summit that it’s time for the continent to have more seats in global institutions.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: Macky Sall, president of the Republic of Senegal since 2012 and current chairman of the African Union, last week at the presidential palace in Dakar, the capital.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, has been arrested and will face criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried in the Bahamas in April.

item.title: Day 13: For a Celebrated Chef, the Tastes and Smells of St. Lucia Day in Sweden Linger
item.description: In his restaurants, including his latest, Marcus Samuelsson draws inspiration from childhood memories of the Scandinavian holiday.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Samuelsson

item.title: 6 Dead, Including 2 Officers, After Shootout in Rural Australia
item.description: The officers and a bystander were gunned down outside a property in Queensland, and the assailants were later killed by the police, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jason O'Brien/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press

item.title: Putin Skips Annual News Conference, Avoiding Possible Questions on War
item.description: The December event has offered reporters rare — albeit stage-managed — chances to pose hard questions. With the war going poorly for Russia, that could have been awkward.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after his year-end news conference in Moscow last December.

item.title: EU Imposes New Sanctions on Iranians Over Supplying Drones to Russia
item.description: Russia has deployed Iranian-made drones in Ukraine since August to attack infrastructure as well as military targets, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, where an Iranian drone struck in October.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China’s Space Push
item.description: Plus China’s vaccination pivot and the year’s most stylish “people.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Chinese astronauts embarked on the Shenzhou 15 rocket on Nov. 29.

item.title: E.U. Roiled by Corruption Investigation Linked to Qatar
item.description: The bloc’s parliament and its executive body are scrambling to manage the fallout as the Belgian authorities continue raids linked to suspected illegal lobbying.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Roberta Metsola, president of the European Parliament, addressing lawmakers in Strasbourg, France, on Monday.

item.title: Ashley Bickerton, Unflinchingly Honest About His Work and Illness
item.description: Last words (and works) of the artist diagnosed with ALS in 2021. A devoted surfer, he chose to live remotely in Bali, away from the buzz. It found him anyway.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Brisick

item.title: In a Wary Arctic, Norway Starts to See Russian Spies Everywhere
item.description: Other European countries are, too, blurring the line between vigilance and paranoia.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An airport employee inside the control tower at the Tromso airport, where traffic has been disrupted by unauthorized drones.

item.title: Can Australia Save a Rare Reptile by Moving It to a Cooler Place?
item.description: An experiment to preserve the western swamp tortoise is the latest flash point in a debate over how far humans should go to protect nature as the world warms.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Matthew Abbott
item.media:description: Releasing a western swamp turtle at Scott National Park in Australia in August.

item.title: A Gunman Kills 3 Women in Rome, Shocking the City
item.description: A man opened fire during a condominium meeting killing three women and wounding four people, shocking a country not accustomed to random acts of mass violence.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Italian Carabinieri, or military police, outside a bar in Rome, where three people were killed Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Hit Hotel Where Members of Russia’s Wagner Group Gathered
item.description: The claim could not be independently verified, and there was no immediate comment or confirmation from the Wagner Group.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: U.K. Snow and Weather: 3 Children Dead After Falling Into Icy Lake
item.description: Freezing temperatures raised concerns about energy costs. Three children died after falling into an icy lake, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Jenny Gross

item.title: Covid, Flu and RSV: Here’s How to Reduce Your Risk
item.description: Covid and flu cases are on the rise.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drive-through Covid test in Los Angeles.

item.title: Russia Is Using Old Ukrainian Missiles Against Ukraine, General Says
item.description: The missiles, returned to Russia in the 1990s under an agreement aimed at assuring Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity, have shown up in rubble.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers combing through the rubble of a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was hit in a Russian attack in October.

item.title: What Happens to the Migrant Workers Who Built the World Cup?
item.description: The World Cup was a $220 billion construction project powered by migrant workers. We went to Nepal — a major source of labor for Qatar — to find out what’s driving workers to do dangerous jobs that many say they can’t afford to lose.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Salazar, Pramod Acharya, Sarah Kerr and Ben Laffin
item.media:credit: Nicole Salazar for The New York Times

item.title: What Will Biden Offer African Leaders at U.S.-Africa Summit?
item.description: China, Russia, Turkey and the United Arab Emirates are all vying for influence in Africa. What will the Biden administration offer at a summit that starts Tuesday in Washington?
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Let no one tell us no, don’t work with so-and-so, just work with us. We want to work and trade with everyone,” said President Macky Sall of Senegal, who is president of the African Union.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The German aristocrat connected to a plot to overthrow the government.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Boris Roessler/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Heinrich XIII during his arrest on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Faces More Outages and Strikes Russian-Controlled Melitopol
item.description: The attack on Melitopol signals the importance of longer-range weapons in Ukraine’s campaign to recapture land in the south.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Matt Stevens and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Hundreds of thousands of people in the Odesa region of Ukraine lacked power on Sunday after Russia attacked infrastructure there.

item.title: Biden’s Top Hostage Negotiator Details the Release of Brittney Griner
item.description: He said he told her “I’m here to take you home” when they met in Abu Dhabi for the prisoner exchange.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

item.title: Indigenous Australians in Murujuga Fight to Preserve Heritage Sites
item.description: In Western Australia, new projects would supercharge gas drilling and processing. Traditional owners of the land say their heritage sites are threatened.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Raelene Cooper, right, at a rock art site on Burrup Peninsula, Australia, also called Murujuga by Aboriginal people. In the background is a Woodside Energy Group gas plant.

item.title: In Hostage Diplomacy, It’s Often the Hostage-Takers Who Pay
item.description: Detaining foreigners to wring concessions from their home country’s government holds perils for both sides, but especially, perhaps surprisingly, for the hostage takers.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: A news conference in November 1979 with 13 of the more than 60 people who were taken hostage at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran that month. This group was released within a few weeks, but the others were held for more than a year.

item.title: 4 Charged With Corruption in Bribery Inquiry Linked to Qatar
item.description: The Belgian authorities announced other charges, including money laundering, in a case involving current and former members of the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Eric Vidal/European Parliament, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Eva Kaili, a Greek politician, has been asked to step down as a vice president of the European Parliament.

item.title: Pants Recovered From Shipwreck Sell for $114,000 at Auction
item.description: The pants and other artifacts auctioned were salvaged from the S.S. Central America, a ship that sank in 1857.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Jason Bean/The Reno Gazette-Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The pants on the right were recovered from a trunk that was aboard the S.S. Central America, which sank in 1857.

item.title: Libyan Charged in 1988 Lockerbie Plane Bombing Is in FBI Custody
item.description: Abu Agila Mohammad Mas’ud, a Libyan bomb expert, is accused of building the explosive device used in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Policemen looking at the wreckage of the 747 Pan Am airliner that exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988.

item.title: Ending a Civil War
item.description: A cease-fire in Ethiopia could bring an end to years of violence.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Redwan Hussein, left, lead negotiator for Ethiopia, and Getachew Reda, right, lead Tigray negotiator, during the peace talks in Pretoria, South Africa on Nov. 2, 2022.

item.title: Prince Heinrich XIII and the Plot to Overthrow Germany’s Government
item.description: Prince Heinrich XIII was arrested last week as the suspected ringleader of a plan to overthrow the German government. Nostalgic for an imperial past, he embraced far-right conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince Heinrich XIII of Reuss’s Waidmannsheil lodge in Bad Lobenstein, Germany.

item.title: For Moldova, War Next Door Brings Energy Crunch and Paid Protests
item.description: The tiny country, starved of natural gas and electricity because of the conflict in neighboring Ukraine, is confronting street rallies bankrolled by a pro-Russian politician to target its pro-Western government.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chisinau, the capital of Moldova, has been the site of paid protests against the country’s pro-Western government.

item.title: Former Prisoner in Iran Welcomes Brittney Griner to a ‘Bizarre Club’
item.description: Dr. Kylie Moore-Gilbert, who was in prison for two years, said she was unable to simply pick up where she left off, quitting her job, traveling and then writing about her experience.
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:description: Kylie Moore-Gilbert speaking at the Australian National University in Canberra, Australia, in February.

item.title: Man Accused in 2015 Terror Attacks in Mali Is Extradited to the U.S.
item.description: Fawaz Ould Ahmed Ould Ahemeid was brought to the United States on Friday and appeared on Saturday before a federal magistrate judge in Brooklyn, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.media:description: Malian soldiers outside the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, the day after an attack in November 2015.

item.title: Belgian Inquiry Into Qatar and Bribery Stuns European Parliament
item.description: The police detained five people, including former and current members of the body, in a case centered on possible attempts to influence the European Parliament’s economic and political decisions.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: The European Parliament building in Brussels. The investigation comes as Qatar is hosting the World Cup amid heightened scrutiny.

item.title: What Happened to the Qatar Women’s National Team?
item.description: A squad that featured in the host nation’s bid to host the World Cup in 2010 hasn’t played a game in eight years.
item.dc:creator: Allison McCann

item.title: Rights Advocates Honored at Nobel Peace Prize Ceremony
item.description: The three recipients of this year’s Peace Prize emphasized the urgency of fighting today’s authoritarian states to secure human rights and democracy.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Oleksandra Matviychuk, the head of the Center for Civil Liberties in Ukraine, speaking during the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony at Oslo City Hall on Saturday.

item.title: German Police Block Off Parts of Dresden After Standoff With Gunman
item.description: The police said they believed that the suspect, whom they identified as a 40-year-old German citizen, had shot his mother before moving on to the center of the city.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers securing the area at a Christmas market in Dresden, Germany, on Saturday.

item.title: Fool’s Paradise
item.description: The finale of “The White Lotus” airs tomorrow. Here’s to being a fan, without going overboard.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The World Comes to Montreal to Reverse a Rise in Species Extinction
item.description: A conversation with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during the United Nations’ biodiversity negotiations in Montreal.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during a meeting with reporters in Montreal this week.

item.title: Jimmy Lai of Hong Kong Gets Five Year Sentence
item.description: Jimmy Lai, the outspoken owner of a pro-democracy newspaper, was sentenced to more than five years in prison for violating terms of a lease contract.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai, center, leaving the Hong Kong’s Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong last year.
